name: Hand-blown recycled Moroccan tea glasses
description:
These subtly beautiful tinted handblown tea glasses have a classic, clean design and are made from 100% recycled glass. Stackable and dishwasher safe. Comes in 3 colors -- clear glass with blueish tint, blue and green, and in multiple sizes. Great for juice, wine, as well as tea.

Sold in sets of 6.

5 inch glasses hold 8oz of water. 

*Glasses may have residue from the hand blowing process and need to be rinsed before using.

name: Moroccan market bag with colored leather handle
description: Hand-woven and built-to-last by women in the Moroccan countryside out of renewable and eco-friendly palm leaves. These chic and supremely useful bags are great for the farmer's market, picnic in the park, or even an overnight trip. They measure approximately 22" x 12" x 10", with leather handles.

name: boucherouite blocks
description:
"Boucherouite" translates in Moroccan to something close to "king of the leftovers." These energetic and eclectic free form rag rugs hand-woven by tribal Berber women from discarded scraps and recycled fabric and materials combine abstract art with ingenuity and resourcefulness. Each carpet is a truly one-of-a-kind and unique work of art. As a recent article in the New York Times stated, "They seem more suitable for framing than trampling underfoot."

“Boucherouite rugs make the tough art of weaving look like fun.” 
– Hollander Cotter, The New York Times

“This new take on an old tradition has yielded some dramatic results and I am a full fledged fan.” 
– Design*Sponge

Measure: 6'10x3'6"

name: Handmade leather saddle bag
description:
A classic and elegant shape updated with vibrant colors. Hand-dyed and hand-stitched sheepskin saddle bag with cross-body strap, 2 front pockets under flap, one that is zippered.  

Measures approximately 10 inches across and 3 inches deep. Strap is approximately 27 inches long, and adjustable.

name: Moroccan Leather Pouf, Bright Colors
description:
Poufs have been a traditional staple of Moroccan home decor for centuries. These handsewn and hand dyed leather poufs can be used as seating, ottomans, stools. Finished with silk embroidery and has a bottom zipper for easy stuffing. 

These poufs are sold unstuffed. To achieve desired firmness, we recommend: kapok fiber, cotton batting, shredded foam, old clothes, towels, blankets. 

Measures: (when stuffed) 17.5” across, 12” high

name: Berber Pillow, killim6
description:
measure: 1'4"x1'4"

One-of-a-kind, vintage hand-woven pillow from the Middle Atlas Mountains in Morocco features traditional tribal patterns. Made with natural wool and dyes.

Delivered unstuffed.

name: leather slippers
description: Berber slippers made in Marrakech medina by our artisan Moustapha are simple, classic, flats that can be worn indoors as well as outside. The choice of leather and finishing has been carefully made, with comfortable padding inside.

name: Boujad
description: Measures: 7'5" x 4'7"

name: Hand-blown recycled  glasses, "basta" size
description:
These subtly beautiful blue-tinted glasses have a classic, clean design and are made from 100% recycled glass. Stackable. 2 inches tall, 2 1/2 inches diameter. Can also be used as candle holder .

*Glasses may have residue from the hand blowing process and need to be rinsed before using.

name: Moroccan Leather Pouf, White
description:
Poufs have been a traditional staple of Moroccan home decor for centuries. These handsewn and hand dyed leather poufs can be used as seating, ottomans, stools. Finished with silk embroidery and has a bottom zipper for easy stuffing. 

These poufs are sold unstuffed. To achieve desired firmness, we recommend: kapok fiber, cotton batting, shredded foam, old clothes, towels, blankets. 

Measures: (when stuffed) 17.5” across, 12” high

name: lemon wood spoons
description: An everyday spoon becomes an objet d'art when made from fine-grained, light-colored lemon wood. A by-product of the citrus industry, Moroccan lemon tree branches that no longer bear fruit are hand carved into these unusual, soft yellow kitchen utensils. As this is an artisanal product, each one is unique and shapes vary slightly. Hand wash recommended.

name: Moroccan Leather Pouf, Brown
description:
Poufs have been a traditional staple of Moroccan home decor for centuries. These handsewn and hand dyed leather poufs can be used as seating, ottomans, stools. Finished with silk embroidery and has a bottom zipper for easy stuffing. 

These poufs are sold unstuffed. To achieve desired firmness, we recommend: kapok fiber, cotton batting, shredded foam, old clothes, towels, blankets. 

Measures: (when stuffed) 17.5” across, 12” high

name: Handmade Moroccan Leather Pouf, neutral colors
description:
Poufs have been a traditional staple of Moroccan home decor for centuries. These handsewn and hand dyed leather poufs can be used as seating, ottomans, stools. Finished with silk embroidery and has a bottom zipper for easy stuffing. 

These poofs are sold unstuffed. To achieve desired firmness, we recommend: cotton batting, shredded foam, kapok fiber, old clothes, towels, blankets. 

Measures: (when stuffed) 17.5” across, 12” high

name: Lemon wood soup spoons
description: A by-product of the citrus industry, Moroccan lemon tree branches that no longer bear fruit are hand carved into these unique, soft yellow kitchen utensils. These simply gorgeous spoons are typically used to eat harira, a traditional Moroccan soup. As each spoon is made by hand, size will vary slightly. Hand wash recommended.

name: Handmade Spiral Safi Plates
description:
Moroccan plates that are hand-painted and hand-glazed, from Safi, a town famous for its pottery. The spirals are an ancient Berber symbol for eternity and are a common motif in Morocco. These bowls are thick with a beautiful glaze and can be used as dinnerware or to display. This work of art is exquisite whether used as a serving piece or displayed with other Moroccan pottery in an eye-catching wall hanging. 10 inch diameter. 

As these are individually handcrafted, none are exactly alike.

name: Colorful Moroccan Braided Leather Bracelets
description: Simply stunning handcrafted bracelets in colorful leather from Marrakech with snap closure. Each measure approximately 2 1/2 inches diameter (8" long flat).

name: Striped Hammam Towel
description:
These foutas are traditionally used at the Moroccan baths. Luxuriously large, each towel is hand-woven. The soft cotton cloth is highly versatile in Morocco where it is used as a scarf on chilly nights in the desert; as a sarong on the beach; as a sunblock when the heat is especially intense; as a shoulder and head-cover when visiting religious sites; and as an emergency towel for last-minute swims.

Measures approximately 77 x 30 inches

name: Hammam towel
description:
These foutas are traditionally used at the Moroccan baths. Luxuriously large, each towel is hand-woven. The soft cotton cloth is highly versatile in Morocco where it is used as a scarf on chilly nights in the desert; as a sarong on the beach; as a sunblock when the heat is especially intense; as a shoulder and head-cover when visiting religious sites; and as an emergency towel for last-minute swims.

Measures approximately 77 x 30 inches

name: boucherouite #82
description:
"Boucherouite" translates in Moroccan to something close to "king of the leftovers." These energetic and eclectic free form rag rugs hand-woven by tribal Berber women from discarded scraps and recycled fabric and materials combine abstract art with ingenuity and resourcefulness. Each carpet is a truly one-of-a-kind and unique work of art. As a recent article in the New York Times stated, "They seem more suitable for framing than trampling underfoot."

“Boucherouite rugs make the tough art of weaving look like fun.” 
– Hollander Cotter, The New York Times

“This new take on an old tradition has yielded some dramatic results and I am a full fledged fan.” 
– Design*Sponge

“Boucherouite rugs make the tough art of weaving look like fun.” 
– Hollander Cotter, The New York Times

“This new take on an old tradition has yielded some dramatic results and I am a full fledged fan.” 
– Design*Sponge
